meanings.sent1: The factory owner decided to proletarianise the workers by reducing their wages.
meanings.sent2: The government's policies aimed to proletarianise the middle class and increase the working class.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick was to proletarianise the wealthy audience members into ordinary citizens.
meanings.sent4: The artist's brush seemed to proletarianise the canvas, turning it into a scene of everyday life.
meanings.sent5: The potion had a strange effect, seeming to proletarianise the cat into a common alley cat.

meanings.definition: To cause to become part of the proletariat.
meanings.sent1: The new laws would proletarianise many small business owners, forcing them to join the working class.
meanings.sent2: The economic downturn threatened to proletarianise a large portion of the population.
meanings.sent3: The unexpected inheritance seemed to proletarianise the wealthy heiress overnight.
meanings.sent4: The storm's destruction seemed to proletarianise the once affluent neighborhood.
meanings.sent5: The revolutionary leader's speeches inspired many to proletarianise and fight for workers' rights.
